slides.templateDescription: Display a long amount of content
Swipe through a group of images

items.caption:
Healthcare information (PHI) is particularly ripe for abuse because it contains **so many** important personal identifiers
(e.g., Social Security Numbers, bank account information).
There’s a common thread to all cybersecurity threats - except natural disasters - there’s a human behind them.
# Now, let's take a closer look at external and internal threats.

question.content: PHI is valuable to hackers because...

answers.content: It's a rich source of many personal identifiers
PHI is available online for patients to access their medical records
It's a rich source of many personal identifiers
PHI is available online for patients to access their medical records

answer.takeaway: Think of all the information that's in PHI and medical records, and how they can be used for financial gain, blackmail (a prominent community member has a socially unacceptable disease) or identity theft.

data.title: PHI is valuable to hackers because...
data.subtitle: Choose the 2 correct answers

slides.templateDescription: Swipe through a gallery of images

images.caption:
# In many ways, **external breaches** are easiest to imagine: after all, we’ll lock our cars or homes, protect our money, tell our kids “stranger danger.”

We get it.
# With external threats, although there’s a **“who,”** all we see is the evidence of the attack - something bad happens.
# **Well-executed analyses**; robust, layered safeguards, including hardware, software and wetware (aka people); and, frequent reviews of safeguards are usually adequate.

question.content: Well-executed analyses; robust, layered safeguards; and, frequent reviews of safeguards are usually adequate to protect against external threats.

answer.takeaway:
There's **never** a simple, easy, single security measure that will address all security threats always, and in the future. That's why HIPAA identifies three sets of safeguards - administrative, physical and technical - that address different source of threats.

Implementing **all** these safeguards, based on ongoing, current analyses of current threats and vulnerabilities, is the best approach.

data.title: Well-executed analyses; robust, layered safeguards; and, frequent reviews of safeguards are usually adequate to protect against external threats.

slides.templateDescription: Swipe through a gallery of images

images.caption: # With internal threats, we have already let the person inside our perimeter.
# They’re in the building, perhaps the office, and maybe even sitting next to us.
# They have access and some level of trust already...
# ...meaning these threats typically take longer to detect.

question.content: Which of the following are true of internal threats?

answers.content: May not be as obvious as an external threat
They typically take longer to detect
They're not as big a risk as an external threat
May not be as obvious as an external threat
They typically take longer to detect
They're not as big a risk as an external threat

answer.takeaway: Internal threats are subtle - after all, the potential perpetrator is already an insider.  These threats, and attacks, are not as apparent as external attacks, and can remain undetected for quite a while.

data.title: Which of the following are true of internal threats?
data.subtitle: Which 3 are true

slides.templateDescription: Display a list of bullet points

data.prompt: Select an item to see more

list.content: Employees or partners who misappropriate resources, break acceptable use policies, mishandle data, install unauthorized applications and use unapproved workarounds; their actions are inappropriate as opposed to malicious, many of which fall within the world of Shadow IT (i.e., outside of IT knowledge and management).
list.title:
**The Careless Worker**
_(misusing assets)_

list.content: Insiders recruited, solicited or bribed by external parties to exfiltrate data.
list.title:
**Inside Agent**
_(stealing information on behalf of outsiders)_

list.content: Insiders who seek to harm their organization via destruction of data or disruption of business activity.
list.title:
**The Disgruntled Employee**
_(destroying property)_

list.content: Actors with access to corporate assets who use existing privileges to access information for personal gain.
list.title:
**The Malicious Insider**
_(stealing information for personal gain)_

list.content: Business partners who compromise security through negligence, misuse, or malicious access to or use of an asset.
list.title:
**The Feckless Third-Party**
_(compromising security)_

data.title: Verizon’s _Insider Threat Report*_  sums it up well:

question.content: Examples of internal threats affecting PHI include...

answer.takeaway: Although office supplies are a valuable asset for an entity, they typically don't have any PHI (unless it's a reused thumbdrive that has not been reformatted or erased completely - but that's a **different  bad practice.**

data.title: Examples of internal threats affecting PHI include...
data.subtitle: There are 3 correct answers
